item.title: Gauging public interest in the death of Justice John Paul Stevens
item.description:
Justice John Paul Stevens died on July XXXX, 2019. He retired about a decade ago and was replaced by Elana Kagen on the bench. Over the last few years I have been investigating when the general public becomes interested in the Supreme Court as an institution, in the Court’s members, and in the cases that the Court decides.

In this post I will look at interest generated by Stevens’ recent death. How do we know if the public is interested? I have explored two tools: Wikipedia page views and Google Trends. Wikipedia reports page views on a daily basis and these are relatively easy to access. Google reports web searching for terms, including people, and reports data through a variety of lenses, both short term and long term, reporting out an index with 100 being the highest search time period. I will also be looking at two measures of media coverage for comparison: cable news coverage as recorded by the XXXX and the number of news stories as collected by XXXX. For all of this data, I have gone back to the beginning of the available Wikipedia page view data, December 2007 with the exception of the cable news data which is only available from XXXX, XXXX.
